content.definition: An aneurysm caused by destruction of the arterial wall by infection. Despite the name, most are bacterial (not fungal) in origin. Results from septic embolism (endocarditis), contiguous spread, or direct trauma with contamination. Rapidly expanding, highly lethal if untreated.

clinical_features.historical_note: Term 'mycotic' coined by Osler describing mushroom-like appearance, not fungal etiology
diagnosis: CT/CTA: saccular aneurysm, irregular wall, perianeurysmal gas/fluid
management: Extra-anatomic bypass through clean tissue planes
In-situ reconstruction with antibiotic-impregnated graft or homograft (selected cases)

clinical_pearls: Mycotic aneurysms grow rapidly - serial imaging essential
Salmonella + aortic aneurysm = classic association (elderly with atherosclerosis)
IVDU + femoral mass = assume infected pseudoaneurysm until proven otherwise
Prosthetic graft in infected field has high reinfection rate
Source control (excision) + antibiotics required for cure
